name: HTTP
title: HTTP

children.text: HTTP is the fundamental component of data transfer for the World Wide Web.
With the HTTP app in Make, you can
connect to API services and applications that don't have an integration with Make
is a new version of the HTTP app that simplifies the setup, ensures more secure keychain storage, and provides native pagination.
You can use the following modules to build your
Both modules support authenticated and unauthenticated requests.
authentication is required, choose one of the following methods as required by the target service's API documentation:
For security reasons, define the authentication details in the dedicated
field rather than passing them through headers or query parameters. This approach provides the following benefits:
Prevents exposure of keys in your requests
Allows easy and safe key rotation
Makes an HTTP request to any server.
Read below how to configure the standard module settings.
Use when no credentials are required for the request (e.g., web scraping).
Use when the service provider requires an API key (token).
Use when the service provider requires a
Use when the service provider requires
client credentials (Client ID and Client Secret)
Add the required credentials based on the selected authentication type:
Enter the URL of an API endpoint (including the base URL), webhook, or webpage, beginning with https://. For example:
Make allows only secure HTTPS. Connections that are using unverified (self-signed) certificates are rejected.
Select the HTTP method you want to use:
: to retrieve information for an entry.
to retrieve the status line and headers,  without the response body.
: to make a partial entry update.
to request information about the operations available for the specified resource or server.
Add headers to provide additional metadata or instructions for the request. For example,
You don't need to use this field to define the authentication credentials and content type, as there are specific module fields for that (i.e.,
to specify or customize your request. This is mostly relevant for
For example, you can specify which contacts or files you want to retrieve or delete. You can find the query parameters in the service's API documentation.
contains the data transferred in an HTTP request. Select the body content type:
Enter data in a JSON format. You can enter data as a
Enter files and form data as key-value pairs. You can use this body content type to send files in the HTTP request,
and you can also add text fields to the request.
form fields as key-value pairs encoded in the URL style. With this body content type, t
he body of the HTTP request sent to the server is one query string.
define the JSON body with a
to map or enter values for each key. JSON reserved characters placed within values will be escaped automatically. This helps to avoid errors related to invalid JSON.
: enter the JSON body as a raw text string. If values contain JSON reserved values, you must escape them manually.
: map the file you want to upload from the previous module, or enter the file name and file data manually.
The keys and values will be encoded in key-value pairs separated by

between the key and the value.
Example of the resulting HTTP request format:
body content type, enter the body content based on the selected
to structure the output data so that its easy to map. All mappable items will be available after you run the module once.

lets you retrieve large data sets in smaller, more manageable parts. Refer to the service's API documentation to see if they allow pagination and which type, and what's needed to configure it. This information is usually provided in the description of a particular endpoint.
If you need to make a paginated HTTP request, select the type of pagination; otherwise, leave the field empty.
you need to use two parameters:
is the starting point or position in the dataset. The
is the maximum number of records that should be included on each page, e.g.,
you need to define which page to retrieve,  using the value of the current page number plus 1, and sometimes the page limit, e.g.,
the server provides the specific, pre-built
you define the last item ID in the current page or map the next page's starting point (depends on the API implementation), e.g.,
Enter the path to the array of items. For example,
Enter the path to the full URL for the next page. For example,
Enter the path to the token or cursor value for the next page. For example,
Enter the query parameter name that defines the number of items to skip. For example,
Enter the number to start the request at. This is typically 0 or 1. You can also use this field to return items beyond Makes 3200 limit.
Enter the query parameter name that defines the page number. For example,
Enter the page number to start the request at. This is typically 0 or 1. You can also use this field to return items beyond Makes 3200 limit.
Enter the query parameter name that defines the last item in the current page or the next pages starting point. For example,
This is typically used when working with items beyond Makes 3200 limit.
Enter the query parameter name that defines the page size. For example,
Enter the maximum number of items to retrieve per page.
Enter the maximum number of items to return. Must be a number between 1 and 3200.
Read below how to configure advanced settings.
Select the TLS handshake method if required by the API's security settings
oth the client and server authenticate each other using certificates. Requires uploading a
: Only the server is required to present a certificate for its authentication
if your network requires routing requests through an intermediary server.
In the pop-up window, configure the following fields:
Enter the domain name or IP address of the proxy server.
Enter the port number used by the proxy server. Must be between 1 and 65535.
: Enter the login name if the proxy requires authentication.
Enter the password for the proxy user
Return error if HTTP request fails
if you want the scenario to stop if the request returns a 4xx or 5xx error.
Enter the maximum time to wait for the response, in seconds.
Must be a number between 1 and 300.
to automatically follow HTTP redirection responses, with a maximum of 10.
to see how the redirection works.
Share cookies with other HTTP modules
to enable the sharing of cookies with other HTTP modules.
to request compression of the response data. Adds the
POST, PUT, PATCH, GET, HEAD, DELETE:
The original method and request body are preserved for the redirected request. Query parameters from the original request are discarded.
These two codes are similar in how
handles them, reflecting a common, albeit non-compliant, practice of early browsers.
The method remains unchanged. The body is preserved. Query parameters are preserved unless
. The body is preserved. Query parameters are preserved unless
The method remains unchanged. The body is preserved. Query parameters are preserved unless
This status code explicitly tells the client to perform a
request to the new location, regardless of the original method.
The method remains unchanged. The body is preserved. Query parameters are preserved unless
The method is always changed to
. The request body is discarded. Query parameters are preserved unless
POST, PUT, PATCH, GET, HEAD, DELETE:
The original method and request body are preserved for the redirected request. Query parameters from the original request are discarded.
Status codes: 305 (Use Proxy), 306 (Switch Proxy), 307 (Temporary Redirect) and 308 (Permanent Redirect)
POST, PUT, PATCH, GET, HEAD, DELETE:
The original method and request body are preserved for the redirected request. Query parameters are preserved unless
Downloads a file from a specified URL.
Read below how to configure the standard module settings.
Use when no credentials are required for the request (e.g., web scraping).
Use when the service provider requires an API key (token).
Use when the service provider requires a
Use when the service provider requires
client credentials (Client ID and Client Secret)
Add the required credentials based on the selected authentication type:
Enter the URL of the file you want to download. You can use the file (map the file data) in other modules in the
Make only allows secure HTTPS. Connections that are using unverified (self-signed) certificates are rejected.
Read below how to configure advanced settings.
Return error if HTTP request fails
if you want the scenario to stop if the request returns a 4xx or 5xx error.
Share cookies with other HTTP modules
to enable the sharing of cookies with other HTTP modules.
Add headers to provide additional metadata or instructions for the request. For example,
to specify or customize your request.
For example, you can specify the file name, file ID, or format. You can find the query parameters in the service's API documentation.

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  a.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-public-space-links-wrap .ab-public-space-link:first-of-type {
    border-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-toc-item-active a{
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 {
    text-decoration-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-left:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .ab-nav-left-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-right:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .ab-nav-right-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

/* Titles in purple */
.ab-link-blocks-wrapper .ab-link-block-item.ab-docs-card-mode .ab-link-block-content-wrap .font-bold {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

</style>

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
